body.p:
I commence my note of acknowledgment with writing a name which
is not according to hebrew grammar quite correct; for silent she
in the middle of a word being an impossible syllable according
to our idiom, but so much is vague in the barbarous tongue called
English. It is rather laughable for you to peak of old age,
as preventing you from reading my beautiful clear handwriting.
Is it not rather a hint that my power of tracing letters is
by reason of lapse of years
on my part? “Sin we wore first acquaint,”
near forty years have elapsed, and the headless stranger
whom you welcomed on the second of may 24 has now almost filled
up the measure of his troubles(?) and behold the dark shadows
of the picture interposing themselves on his sunlight; and if
you feel that time has flown past you not without leaving his
mark, for good or ill, can it be otherwise with me? I can indeed
make my figures a little mor palinly if I choose to draw my
pen more carefully over the paper; but every moment so devoted
is so much taken form the rapidity of time8s flight, and then
1 and then ? scratch so much for the men of the press who
are all readers of heiroglyphics, that i have come to fancy al
the world printers, if not players in the Shakespearian sense.

“the hand of every man seals his deeds
in the book of the divine record” is a beautiful opinion of the
ages of Israel, and in this regard we all make our mark; hence
you can readilly imagine that I have some good reasons for
carefully writing, and especially to you who are a ?
Now I have given you quotations enough, and I trust ample apolo
for the trouble that I cause you have to get to the depth of
my last ? mysterious contents.

Well good doctor, I know not that i have written for years
as much light correspondence as above. I have
a few to whom I write more than mere business, except H. N Nathan
of St Thomas now, though late of Jamaica. It is with me the
constant roll of the wheel of labor, writing for the public,
speaking to the people, and reading to qualify myself for
these tasks.

I must still fall back on my idea of ?
in lending the book, money should not have been mentioned.
Though nearly the whole of the plan may be useless, still the
idea of the ventilating chimney, I think is worth adapting. I
know not whether your architect will have the ght? of it. At the
same time the work may be fitly placed in the library of the
hospital, when erected as a mention of what had been done
elsewhere. When it is ready for opening I shall, if living, give
you a few useful books of my own manufacture! Only think how
I speak of literature, as an article of ordinary production,
?; but it is true nonetheless.

I had the pleasure of a visit yesterday of Miss R E Cohen
and Miss Laura Mordecai. They were both well and I was truly
glad to see them.

Let me hear how you progress with the hospital, which I
trust may soon stand forth as a monument of Jewish liberality.
I wont say Israelitish to please your brother Col M. but it is
rather long as I experienced in translating the transactions.

By the by, the complete rendue des Seances received
the day before yesterday of that institution shows it is weekly

leaving England in the rear. What a folly it was in Americans n

not to work with the Board of Delegaten, for then we
should have been something else, and able to aid
effectually in advancing our cause. But folly rules
the hour.
